0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono: Typhoid fever; Prophylaxis: 1 capsule ORALLY x 4 doses, on days 1, 3, 5, and 7, to be completed at least one week prior to potential exposure; booster dose (4-capsule course) every 5 years if re-exposure expected (same schedule)

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• safety and efficacy have not been established in children less than 6 years of age
  • Typhoid fever; Prophylaxis: 6 years and older, 1 capsule ORALLY x 4 doses, on days 1, 3, 5, and 7, to be completed at least one week prior to potential exposure; booster dose (4-capsule course) every 5 years if re-exposure expected (same schedule)

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• acute febrile illness
  • deficiency in ability to produce a humoral or cell-mediated immune response (either congenital or acquired immunodeficiency including treatment with immunosuppressive or antimitotic drugs); safety not demonstrated
  • hypersensitivity to any component of the vaccine or the enteric-coated capsule

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• concomitant use with sulfonamides and antibiotics; may prevent induction of a protective immune response
  • concomitant use with proguanil when used as a single agent (not available in the United States); administer proguanil only if at least 10 days have elapsed since administering the final dose of live typhoid vaccine
  • continue to take precautions against exposure to typhoid organisms (ie, avoid contact or ingestion of potentially contaminated food or water); vaccine protection is not universal
  • gastrointestinal illness, acute; vaccination not recommended
  • persistent diarrhea or vomiting; postpone taking vaccine
  • to report adverse events, contact the Vaccine Adverse Event Reporting system at 1-800-822-7967

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono:
• WHO: Compatible with breastfeeding.
  • Micromedex: Infant risk is minimal.

2.mono:

  • Leflunomide (established)
  • Vaccinia Immune Globulin, Human (probable)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Following the oral ingestion of live typhoid vaccine, which is an attenuated strain of Salmonella typhi TY21a (S. typhi), a quantity of complete lipopolysaccharide sufficient to generate a local protective immune response is synthesized in the intestinal tract, therefore preventing disease..

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Oral
  • administer capsule one hour before a meal with a cold or lukewarm drink (not to exceed body temperature) on alternate days (e.g., days 1, 3, 5, and 7)
  • capsules should not be chewed
  • complete immunization (ingestion of all 4 doses) should be completed at least one week prior to exposure

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• This vaccine may cause abdominal pain, rash, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, headache, or fever.
  • Advise patient to complete immunization dosing at least one week prior to potential exposure.
  • Instruct patient to take capsule 1 h prior to meals with cold or lukewarm drink.
  • Patient should call healthcare professional if a dose is missed, as vaccine should be given on a fixed schedule.
